0: BEIJING China's top leader-in-waiting Xi Jinping, who has set off a storm of rumors after not showing up at scheduled public events for more than a week, is nursing an ailment, possibly a back injury suffered while swimming, sources said on Tuesday. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Xi, who is due to take over the presidency of the world's second-largest economy in March next year, has skipped several meetings with visiting foreign leaders and dignitaries over the past week, including U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and the prime ministers of Singapore and Denmark. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR China's government, however, has declined to spell out what is ailing Xi, 59 - in keeping with decades of official secrecy over the health of senior leaders, a tradition viewed in the West as out of step with a modern state and emerging superpower. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Xi injured his back when he went for his daily swim," a source close to the Beijing leadership said after Xi's absence from the public stage was first noticed last week. At that stage, he had failed to keep scheduled meetings with Clinton and Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The source declined to give further details on the injury, including exactly when and where the incident took place. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Another source also said the injury happened when Xi went swimming. "Xi pulled a (back) muscle when he went swimming," the source said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A third source, citing people close to Xi, said: "He's unwell, but it's not a big problem." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR All three sources spoke on condition of anonymity. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The lack of an official explanation has fuelled Internet speculation surrounding Xi's condition, and brought some pointed questions at briefings by China's foreign ministry. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR On Tuesday, the ministry's spokesman Hong Lei was asked whether Xi is in good health. Sticking to his government's usual reticence, Hong said he had no information to give. But he appeared dismissive of any hint that Xi might be in a bad way. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I hope you can ask a serious question," Hong said when asked to confirm that Xi was alive. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR SEARCHES BLOCKED NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR China's popular Twitter-like microblogging site Sina Weibo blocked searches for Xi's name, as is common with top leaders, but users as usual found ways to skirt the restrictions, referring to Xi as "the crown prince". NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "What's up with the crown prince? He's vanished for the last 10 days or so and the whole world is wondering where he is," wrote one user. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Despite the panicky rumors, some of China's top officials continued to travel outside Beijing -- not what would be expected if the leadership was consumed with crisis. Premier Wen Jiabao gave a speech in the northern port city of Tianjin, and his likely successor, Vice Premier Li Keqiang, was visiting a northwestern region, according to state media reports. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Xi had been scheduled to meet visiting Danish Prime Minister Helle Thorning-Schmidt on Monday afternoon for a photo opportunity, according to a media advisory that had been circulated on September 5. But the event did not take place. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Thorning-Schmidt told Reuters in an interview that a meeting with Xi had never been on her program, which was released on Friday. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I think there has been a slight misunderstanding," she said. "I would, of course, very much like to see him (Xi) and I think I will see him at some stage, perhaps on my next visit to China, but he was never in my program which we released on Friday, so there shouldn't be anything new in my not seeing him." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The foreign ministry's website shows Xi's most recent public appearance was at a ceremony at the ruling Communist Party's Central Party School in Beijing on September 1. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The rumors about Xi come at a tempestuous time for Chinese politics. The 18th Communist Party Congress, at which China's next top leaders including Xi are likely to be unveiled, is set to take place in October. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Earlier this year, senior politician Bo Xilai, once seen as a candidate for the top rung of party leadership, was suspended from the Politburo and his wife convicted of murdering a British businessman. The wife, Gu Kailai, was given a suspended death sentence last month. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR In another scandal this month, a senior ally of President Hu Jintao was demoted after sources said the ally's son was involved in a deadly crash involving a luxury sports car. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR China has been engulfed in the past by rumors about senior leaders. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Last year, the official Xinhua news agency was forced to come out with a one-line statement in English denying former President Jiang Zemin
